Message.Title: Transitioning Apple At Critical Juncture
Message.Msg: Growing pains/competition & declining margins aside, innovation takes time. In the meantime, the quickest fix for this broken stock or easiest tourniquet for a badly bleeding shareprice is to significantly raise the dividend while shareholders patiently waiting for whatever the "next big thing" may be. Orherwise, anxiety and restlessness grows while the big institutional/hedge fund money, the Coopermann's of the world, exit in droves and will probably never come back. A constantly depreciating stock will frighten away new investors, especially value investors, let alone retain loyal ones. The super high growth days are gone as is the Jobs' premium. Let the Board lead by example and show other companies how well and quickly they respond to the needs of shareholders by doing what's right. Otherwise, hubris (as shown to one of its biggest shareholders in Einhorn), general apathy, and/or just one failed new product launch (iTv/Watch) will spell terminal catastrophy for this once Wall Street darling as it will stagnate for decades like so many other tech behemoths before it. The late February meeting should be a catalyst. If Apple is twice as good a company as any in the S&P, it should double its dividend, which is stingy at 2.3%, only equal to inflation or the S&P's yield, and serves no buffer for such a strong downtrend as the company is in currently. At the current rate of price decline, the yield is growing, but for the wrong reason.

Message.Title: BBRY, SNE, NOK are not "Making It"
Message.Msg: Each of these supposed alternatives in smartphones, its turning out, are not "making out well enough" in the smartphones, despite new products. It turns out they are not making a dent in Apple's 70% share of the Smartphone Market's Profits, and/or their new products are "bombing". Each of the above company's Rimm /Blackberry, Sony and Nokia are also still in financial trouble and unlikely to earn money. So CNBC's pushing or reporting that each will be more competition for APPLE, just isn't "panning out". 1. BBRY's new Z10 Phone, not only is it delayed for actual sales in the all important US Market for at least another month, but it's got 1/10th the number of Apps. developed for it as IPHONE, and even though its Blackberrys newest product, its not even caught up to the performance of Apple's last model iPHONE. 2. SONY. Its just been reported that APPLE's IPHONE is now the leading selling smartphone in JAPAN. Which shows even the Japanese prefer the superior Apple iOS experience, better working and more secure software than the Android-powered Sony smartphones. Plus SNE continues to hemorrhage cash so had to sell its NY and Tokyo Skyscrapers to raise $2 billion to cover its losses. 3. NOK. Not only has its Lumia / Windows Smartphone bombed in USA (they only got 1% market share), but its now being reported its BOMBED IN CHINA as well. Also very little market share there. Apple on other hand has upped its sales in China by over 67% in the past year, and grew them over 100% the prior year. BBRY, SNE and NOK all continue to LOSE MONEY AND THEIR CASH TO RUN THEIR BUSINESSES IS DWINDLING. LAST QUARTER ALONE, APPLE MADE MORE POSITIVE CASH-FLOW THAN BBRY + SNE + NOK HAVE ALTOGETHER.

Topic.Title: Those who lost money in AAPL will hate it's products

Message.Msg: You comment is very astute. There was so much "psychology" wrapped up in owning an AAPL product and the fact that every one who bought was in some way "part of the American success story" was a component, I am sure. It was "AAPLE," and now just another struggling (sales) company. Yes, it has lots of cash, but investors realize they will never see it and even if they do, it would only be a very small amount of money a share. AAPL is caught in a terrible conundrum. They must lower their product prices which will compress their margins and make investment in the company even less desirable. It would not surprise me if this build-up of cash will be used to support deep cuts in prices and we will begin to see a price war which will make it clear that the product is simply a commodity with a lot of equal or very near equal quality. Samsung is not exactly a small family run business with no experience in design or production.

Message.Title: Reply to Doerner article in the Economist
Message.Msg: I see you wouldn't even sign your name to this hit piece, this alleged piece of journalism. Where were the journalists when this man was being burned alive? Oh the cops said "Pretty please don't film this?" You're not even a sorry excuse for the 4th estate in a democracy. We on the internet already know that while nothing survived that fire except a drivers license, that the LA Times had reported the day b4 that the same driver's license was found in Mexico. Perhaps as an ex cop he was so respectful of the rule of law that he stopped at the DMV to get a new one. Or perhaps you are lap dogs to power ready to spread any lie that feeds your sorry lazy fat face. I'll say this for Doerner, at least he didn't shoot up a grade school or a McDonald's. He went after the perpetrators of the BS. And if more people who were about to go on shooting rampages targeted the true objects of their rage I bet racist fascist organizations like the LAPD and Wall St would think twice b4 perpetrating such BS. Its a tragedy all the way around. But the greatest victim is democracy when the cops can summarily execute a defendant (innocent until proven guilty) and the press reports every piece of filth that it is spoon fed. Once again thank God for the internet. The media will again be shown to be a poor excuse for a Propaganda Wing. May God truly sort out who is right and wrong and may all public servants who betray the public trust get what they have coming to them all at once. May Peace Prevail on Earth.

Message.Title: 5 Stocks poised for big growth! Read.
Message.Msg: Apple's days of growth are far from over. The technology giant is continuing to come out with new cutting edge merchandise, and thanks to legions of devoted fans and tech-lovers, Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) continues to grow. 2012 wasn't such a great year for Apple, though. In November 2012, Apple was down 24% from their all-time high of $705 per share. At this time of this publication, Apple's stock stands around $465, a far cry from its all-time high, but that doesn't mean that Apple should be ruled out just yet. Between the years 2003 and 2012, Apple has increased its value by 200 fold. Apple has a strong portfolio, market resilience, and some of the most sought after merchandise in the world. 2013 should be a major improvement upon their disappointing 2012 postings.

Message.Title: JANA Partners Liquidates Apple Holdings
Message.Msg: Another Large Hedge Fund Says 'Arrivederci' to Apple (AAPL) Stake Leon Cooperman's Omega Advisors isn't the only hedge fund getting bearish on Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL). According to a 13F filed by JANA Partners for the quarter ended December 31, 2012, the firm has also liquedated its stake in the maker of iPhones, iPads, and other gadgets. Before exiting, JANA held a 143,148 stake in Apple, valued at $75,738,175.32 as of December 31st. The firm didn't specify when the stake was sold, or if it was sold in multiple parts.

Message.Title: China Mobile Could Find Its Next Leg Of Growth Outside Of China
Message.Msg: China Mobile Could Find Its Next Leg Of Growth Outside Of China(Reasons why Apple & CM could dominate) Germany: According to Research and Markets, Germany is the largest wireless market in Western Europe with 114 million subscribers and an estimated $54 billion market size. The country provides an interesting opportunity for China Mobile to leverage its TD-LTE expertise thanks to its significant investments and field studies in the technology. The penetration of 4G LTE in Germany is currently at 3% and estimated to rise to near 20% by 2017. TD-LTE has benefits due to the relative availability and cost of TDD spectrum (compared to FDD spectrum which is used for most LTE networks). As smartphone penetration rises and data usage sees a corresponding increase, the early adoption of 4G LTE will help carriers in Germany avoid a spectrum crunch similar to the one that American carriers are currently experiencing. South Africa: South Africa is the largest wireless market in Africa at 54 million subscribers, [1] accounting for nearly 13% of the total subscribers on the continent. The 4G rollout in South Africa is still in its nascent stage and with China Mobile’s technical prowess, it has the leverage to partner with an existing carrier. Presently, there are four operators: Vodacom, MTN, Cell C and Telkom. Among the four carriers, Cell C can be considered a contender for a potential partnership with China Mobile. Cell C has invested in HSPA+ and is lagging behind Vodacom and MTN in terms of subscribers. Cell C is majority owned by Oger Telecom (division of Saudi Oger).

Topic.Title: China Mobile Could Find Its Next Leg Of Growth Outside Of China

Message.Msg: Part 2: Brazil: The emerging market would be an exciting opportunity for China Mobile. Brazil currently has nearly 257 million subscribers and all of its carriers are testing LTE networks. Also Brazil doesn’t have MVNOs, and thus China Mobile would need to find an existing carrier to partner with. Oi Movel could benefit from a JV with China Mobile, as Oi is the smallest wireless carrier and is losing subscribers. A joint venture with China Mobile would allow the company to leverage China Mobile’s experience with building out TD-LTE as well as its resources, allowing it to better compete with the bigger players. Oi Movel recently announced a technological collaboration with Portugal Telecom, and may be open for further partnerships. Portugal: The wireless market in Portugal is similar to China’s. It has three primary operators – TMN (7.3 million subscribers), Vodafone Portugal (6.6 million) and Optimus (2.5 million) – which control the market. Portugal Telecom has a market cap of around $5 billion, and could be within the reach of China Mobile. Portugal is going through a major recession and with record unemployment, it might not make financial sense to enter this market at this stage. However, on the other hand, the comparatively low valuations could motivate China Mobile to get its foot in the door in a developed market. North Korea: North Korea currently has one wireless provider, Koryolink, which is a joint venture between Orascom Telecom and the government. The carrier recently announced crossing a million subscribers and given the small market size, it would be interesting to see why China Mobile would want to venture. After staying away from the international markets for a while, now could be a good time for China Mobile to pursue overseas ventures to leverage its LTE expertise. The long term benefits of TD-LTE, primarily the availability of spectrum, make it attractive to carriers. Although it is too early to say if China Mobile will go ahead with its international plans, the company’s interest in researching potential markets is a positive sign that the company is not resting on its achievements in China and is hungry for growth.

Topic.Title: Does Pureinvestor Still Post Here?

Message.Msg: If you don't mind me horning in on the thread, replacing stock with deep in the money calls is a great strategy for low yield stocks. And the daily volatility of AAPL overwhelms the ~ 2.3% dividend. Same upside, less exposure to catastrophic loss (you can only lose the purchase price of the calls) and you commit much less cash on a per share basis. The only caution is to avoid taking too big a position ... you will be highly leveraged and the value of your positions will be much more volatile than they would be just holding stock. To mitigate some of that risk you could, of course, sell near term upside calls against one or both of your Jan 2013 long calls. You may be able to repeat that process several times before January expiry. Good luck.

Message.Title: Myths about Jobs and innovation
Message.Msg: Jobs wasn't the great innovator eveyone makes him out to be....he didn't invent the mac, ipod, ipad etc Jobs was infamous for stealing/borrowing great ideas from others: Mac --- Xerox PARC iPod - -- Tony Fadell invented it and brought it to Apple iPhone - agglomeration of many ideas already on the market iPad ---- agglomeration of many existing technologies Hence, Apple is in no great danger without Jobs and innovation is really taking what was done or being done and assembling it into something new that people never knew they needed --- all great inventors say that they stand on the shoulders of giants (those who've innovated things in the past).

Topic.Title: Does Pureinvestor Still Post Here?

Message.Msg: Ok. I understand what you are trying to do. It isn't a bad idea to buy back the covered call since you have already captured 80% of its permium. But I wouldn't sell the shares and replace them with 2 calls at this time. Here is why. Buying straight call, even DITM LEAPS, is an aggressive trade. You only make money if the stock moves up and soon. It is riskier than owning stock. The only time I will buy straight call is when a stock breaks out of a key resistance of a confirmed uptrend and most indicators are lining up to support the bull move. I will monitor the trade very closely and get out at the first sign of trouble. It is all about the odds of success. If a stock breaks out, the odds of going a lot higher is increased. But if it doesn't, it can go down or be in a trading range for awhile and you lose time value while you wait. Just look at MSFT in the last 10 years. Also buying straight call is always a short term trade. Long dated call is only for reducing time value erosion. It doesn't mean you should hold it until expiration. When I buy call I usually buy 2 to 3 times longer than I intended to hold. For example, if I want to hold a call for 2 months, I will buy something expiring in at least 4 to 6 months. Another thing you need to consider is taxes. If you close out the trade now, you will have to pay capital gain taxes on both your shares and the covered call. I know the reason of your strategy change. You are feeling regrets that the covered call you sold had limited your gain when Apple reached 705 so you are telling yourself that you won't miss the chance again this time. But you are turning the risk profile 180 degree from a conservative strategy into a very risky one. I am not saying that you should never replace stocks with calls, but now isn't the right time to do it, IMHO.

Message.Title: I'm done - have fun and GLTA!
Message.Msg: Regardless of the pumpers on CNBC, who get paid to say the markets will keep going up, I just got stopped out and will remain in cash at least until mid-March. This market needs to correct and AAPL will likely reach the levels everyone has been predicting for quite a while. Too many potential market rockers coming e.g. massive govt. budget cuts on 3/1 (anyone who thinks our politicians will reach an agreement is wrong), new elections in Italy, Spain is troubling and don't get me started on England. Follow Buffet if you dare, but he never invests in Tech and only comes on CNBC when he see's potential near-term doom for the markets. AAPL will go down just like the rest of the market, even though it certainly doesn't deserve it. While it may be true that investing in the U.S. is better than obvious foreign markets, it doesn't do AAPL any good because they have already saturated the U.S. market. I'll be sitting on the side lines and playing it safe - GLTA!!

Message.Title: 2nd Largest Apple Shareholder Fidelity Begins Liquidation In SEC Filing
Message.Msg: 2nd Largest Apple (AAPL) Fidelity Sells 4M Shares February 14, 2013 2:29 PM EST In an amended 13G filing on Apple, Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL), Fidelity parent FMR LLC disclosed a 4.41%, or 41,472,327 share, stake in the company. This is down 8.84% from the 45,494,145 shares held at the end of the latest quarter ending September 30, 2012. FMR is the second largest Apple holder behind BlackRock.

Message.Title: Mindich's Eton Park Sells Out of 250K Apple Stake in Q4 In Institutional Trend
Message.Msg: Mindich's Eton Park Sells Out of 250K Apple (AAPL) Stake in Q4 February 14, 2013 1:57 PM EST Eric Mindich's Eton Park Capital Management also took a bit on heed on continuing to hold Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) shares. According to a 13F filed with the U.S. SEC, Eton Park held zero shares of Apple at December 31, 2012. That's down from 250,000 shares held for the prior quarter. Though sales and trades are disclosed on an individual basis, Apple's share price of $529.09 at the end of December suggests a stake of $132,272. The move follows quarterly disclosures from Leon Cooperman's Omega Advisors and JANA Partners made recently.

Message.Title: Gawd!! Hedgies Still Bailing..
Message.Msg: John Burbank's Passport Capital sold all its stake in the fourth quarter, according to a 13F. The fund owned 60,736 shares for the quarter ended 9/30/2012, according to a 13F. Eric Mindich's Eton Park Capital Management sold all of its Apple stake in the fourth quarter, according to a 13F filing with the SEC. The hedge fund had 250,000 shares at the end of the third-quarter, according to that 13F. Barry Rosenstein's JANA Partners sold its stake in Q4. At the end of Q3, the hedge fund held 143,148 shares of the tech giant, the Q3 13F filing shows. Leon Cooperman's Omega Advisors dumped its stake. He previously had 266,404 shares of the tech giant's stock at the end of the third quarter, according to a filing.

Message.Msg: I heard talking head (Jeff Macke) saying Apple is not a growth company. It is above his short call price right now. Well now Einhorn just got "Cook'd" He's going to be sitting on a pile of shares at a loss which will kill his fund performance. His superstar status is fading fast. If he was really good he would cut and run. Easier to deploy that cash into some great winners. I bought KORS and Consteallation just a week ago. Now look at both. Much faster horses to ride out there now that apple is a broken stock. If he wants to wait on a 4% yield to beat the market while the stock sits stagnant or goes down he's going to be staring at a very bad record these next few years. I think he hoped he could Einhorn Apple but it did not work. No big spike over 500 or 600 so he could bail as the sheep follow him. Just did not work this time and the more bad calls he makes like CMG and Apple the fewer sheep will follow him. Ever notice how when cramer started out he would mention a stock on his show and it would skyrocket? Now he mentions stocks and they don't even let out a whimper.

Topic.Title: Apple Not a Growth Company?

Message.Msg: Good point. Even with reduced growth expectations vs. last year (meaning its not growing amazing 50% in sales and earnings), Apple's still growing alot faster than most other companies in terms of sales (which were up over 25% last quarter adjusted for same # weeks vs. prior accounting period, or up 18% even without such adjustment). However earnings barely grew. But of course Apple had unusually high gross profit margin% the prior year, at over 40%, and that came down some. Over all, yes Apple's still growing faster than most "growth companies" in the S&P500. Just that CNBC still has an agenda here, rather than just reporting the news.

Topic.Title: Apple Not a Growth Company?

Message.Msg: Well I can tell you the PE will be going up quite a bit in 2013 and 2014 unless the price comes down more. As the "E" in PE falls it will be higher than Intel and many others unless the price falls to keep it in check. I estimate apple to earn $40 in 2013 and less than $34 per share in 2014. I'm looking for a further decline where it levels off to around $28 to $32 per share in EPS for 2015. They will take out of the stock at least another 30 to 40 per share in dividends and buybacks between now and then. Therefore the cash will not grow much more where it is now. In 2015 it will be trading at 15 times EPS which will be pricey unless the stock falls to around $300 to $350 to bring the PE in line with its declining earnings

Topic.Title: AAPL is solid! I've listed my reasons. Too many short posts that say nothing on this board.

Message.Msg: OK, so he was wrong in Dec 8, 2012, it now is $14 below $480. But at the start of this week Feb. 10, 2013 it had been $480 - 484 until Cook made comments putting down Einhorn's proposal for distributing free Preferred Stock to existing shareholders. In any case, the stock isn't that differently priced than in Dec. 2012, and the Earnings at end of Jan. 2013 rather than drop the stock from about $500 to about $460 could have gone the other way. In fact as Cook indicated if it was a comparable 14 week instead of 13 week quarter, sales would have been up 25% instead of 18% and earnings would have been up alot more than the slight 1% increase. Fact is Apple also had the most amazing quarter from Pos. Cash-Flow: $23 billion added, before paying out the dividend...etc. So its not surprising Einhorn is greedy for more cash payout.

Topic.Title: Truth CNBC "infomercial program" doesn't want you to know:

Message.Msg: Tim Cook at the Goldman conference: To put the 23 million iPads sold in the last quarter in some context, HP, who is the world's largest PC seller, in that same quarter, sold 15 million PCs. So 50+ percent more iPads were sold in that quarter than PCs, and in fact if you look at the full year last year, there were more iPads sold than HP sold of their entire PC lineup. And so there has been a sea change here, but I think we're in the early innings of this game." Today, Gartner Research issued a press release concerning the dire shape that the personal computer market as we know it is in. It's clear that PC's, as in traditional desktops and notebooks "will continue to be marginalized," stated one of Gartner's analysts. Yet stats are only one part of the equation and there may be a glimmer of hope for the PC on the horizon.

Message.Title: Einhorn Buys 275,000 Calls = Super Bagholder
Message.Msg: Greenlight's stake in Apple was increased by about a fifth in the fourth quarter, to 1.3 million shares from 1.1 million shares. The filing also showed a position of 275,000 call options. Call options give shareholders the right to buy shares at a set price by a designated date.

Message.Msg: If Apple doesn't release a bigger iphone till the middle of 2014 their stock will test $300. They'll have hadhad essentially the same phone for over 4 years. It will be a case of too little too late when they release one in 2014 after they are forced to by plummeting iphone sales. Who wants to upgrde to the same phone year after year. if aapl released a 5inch iphone tomorrow Do you think the stock would be green? what about a 4-inch iphone6, would the drop be 10, 20, 30%? It's in human being's nature to want something new, something better, and aaple is not delivering. And don't even say that aapl has unknown products that will be released. For the last couple years, the public has seen aapl's finished products through leaks b4 they're even announced, usually months prior. Short with impunity.

Message.Title: Parade Of Bailing Fundies Are Killing Stock Price!!
Message.Msg: Apple's deep stock slide during 2012 was linked to massive unloading by several hedge funds, according to documents filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, discovered by Reuters. Omega Advisors, for instance, sold all of its 266,000 Apple shares during the fourth quarter of 2012. Eton Park Capital Management sold the entirety of its 600,000 shares in a period spanning the third and fourth quarters. Jana Partners dumped its full 143,000 shares, while Farallon Capital sold off 137,000. It's not clear what prompted the sell-offs, but they may have been triggered by worries about more aggressive competition, lower profit margins, and corporate shakeups. Apple stock also surged quickly in the first half of 2012, which may have prompted funds to divest for the sake of a temporary windfall and the ability to buy back in later at a cheaper price. Some partial unloading was done by Coatue Management, which dropped 18 percent of its shares, and Tiger Global Management, which got rid of 19 percent. Coatue ended up with 643,000 shares at the end of 2012, whereas Tiger Global had a little over 1 million. A separate company, Tiger Management, cut holdings by 28 percent to 42,000.

Message.Title: LONDON (Reuters) - The euro and shares fell sharply on Thursday after data showed the euro zone's two biggest economies shrank even more than expected late last year, throwing a first quarter regional recovery into doubt.
Message.Msg: LONDON (Reuters) - The euro and shares fell sharply on Thursday after data showed the euro zone's two biggest economies shrank even more than expected late last year, throwing a first quarter regional recovery into doubt. The German economy contracted 0.6 percent in the final quarter of 2012, marking its worst performance since the global financial crisis was raging in 2009. Exports, normally the motor of its economy, did most of the damage. Overall the euro zone's 17-country economy shrank 0.6 percent, with France's 0.3 percent fall slightly worse than forecast. Germany is expected to rebound but the figures suggest the bloc as a whole could remain in recession in the first quarter of this year, despite a recent jump in market sentiment as fears that the currency bloc could fall apart faded. "These are horrible numbers. It's a widespread contraction, which does not match this positive picture of stabilization and positive contagion," said Carsten Brzeski, an economist at ING. The data pushed the euro down 0.9 percent to $1.3324, its lowest in three weeks. European shares likewise fell, with Frankfurt and Milan losing more than 1 percent. Paris and London also suffered heavy drops, and the FTSEurofirst 300 index was 0.4 percent lower. "We still expect growth to return in the course of 2013 but any return of growth will be very small which means that the social impact of this recession, especially in the peripheral countries, will be still a very severe one," Brzeski added. German bonds rose as demand for traditional safe-haven assets returned. Bund futures were 55 ticks higher on the day at 142.60, having extended gains after Italian GDP figures also came in weak. Italy, which holds parliamentary elections in just over a week, suffered its sixth successive quarterly fall in GDP - this time a sharp 0.9 percent - putting it into a longer recession than it suffered during the crisis of 2008/2009. Italian bond yields rose 3 basis points on the day to 4.42 percent while those on the Spanish equivalent were 2.5 basis points higher at 5.23 percent.

Message.Title: All the sellers are cleaned out
Message.Msg: So today we found out that most of the legacy owners are now cleaned out, but Soros, and Einhorn have increased their shares. What does this mean? To me, this is capitulation. We needed this badly and some confirmation. I think now we see new money come in and the stock start to slowly rise. The volume has come down quite a bit and that also tells me we will see less manipulation that we saw back in Nov and Dec. Think about it, something must have leaked because we saw the same pattern every day in Dec. Premkt rise, then fall. We are not seeing that as much these days. I guess we'll know more at the end of the month, but for now, I think we have a real bottom in place.

Message.Title: All ex GS managers responsible for taking AAPL up to 700 and then dumping it to public
Message.Msg: Big surprise there, they did the same with oil when they drove it up to 140 in 2008 and then had it crash back down to 60. Mindich, named the youngest partner ever at Goldman Sachs before starting his Eton Park Capital Management fund in 2004, got out of Apple entirely in the fourth quarter after making big sales in the third quarter as well. Eton owned 600,000 shares at the beginning of 2012. Farallon Capital, the hedge fund founded by Steyer, sold 137,000 shares. Steyer, who once worked on the Goldman Sachs risk arbitrage desk under Robert Rubin, stepped down at the end of the year from the firm, which he founded in 1986. Rubin served as U.S. Treasury secretary from 1995 to 1999.

Topic.Title: All ex GS managers responsible for taking AAPL up to 700 and then dumping it to public

Message.Msg: First of all-Goldman doesn't 'take' the stock anywhere. If you think they do-quit trading right now. They trade the price action of the stock just like the rest of the world. As far as getting out in the 4th quarter of last year-if you've got 20/20 vision & can look at a chart, you'll see that the price trend of the stock turned down & has been down for the last 5 1/2 months. There's no reason to be long a stock in a downtrend-unless you like losing money-thus he bailed out of apple. Play the price trend of the stock & turn off the TV. Good luck.

Topic.Title: Max Pain for feb 16 options is..... going into this morning is

Message.Msg: 470 close tommorrow. Its pretty easy to do if you`re a big firm with deep pockets. Ping it back and forth all day so it don`t get too far out of reach and at the close put in numerous matching buys and sells.The price is then pinned at almost exactly where it needs to be. The major funds are all on the same page also. I used to do it every day. Don`t forget that electronic traders still get to trade even after retail is done. (example: we are done at 4:00 E.T. and they still execute trades)

Message.Title: Here are real news details of a dividend payable to Feb 11 shareholders. Hope you weren't short that day!!!
Message.Msg: Many more catalysts coming. This should drive us up nicely tomorrow!!! Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is set to pay out its third dividend sum to shareholders on Friday. The company is scheduled to distribute about $2.5 billion at $2.65 per share across its 939 million outstanding shares. Shareholders on record as of February 11 will receive payment. The company also decided to start buying back stock from board members and other executives of the company. Apple is one of the highest dividend payers in the U.S. in absolute terms, its cash position is worth $137 billion at the end of December. Some experts believe an announcement of a dividend increase can help resurrect the company’s share price, proving to be the catalyst it has sorely lacked over the past few months…
